desc: Day School first opened by the Presbyterian Church in a small building erected on the Little Black Bear Reserve.
After initially closing due to Aunsettled conditions brought about by the Riel Rebellion@ and low attendance, the Day School was reopened in September.
File Hills Boarding School opened under the auspices of the Presbyterian Church in March.
In September, the Day School was closed and its students began attending File Hills Boarding School.
File Hills IRS was closed on June 30.

writtenAgreements.desc: 1911 agreement between the Foreign Mission Committee of the Presbyterian Church in Canada and the Federal Government for the operation and management of the school. Although the United Church took the administration of the school in 1925, no agreement between the United Church and the Department of Indian Affairs was found.

additionalInformation.notes: Deaf student claimed that he had significant difficulty in classroom and as a result the teacher lost patience with him and '[b]oxed his ears'. Also indicated that he was constantly teased by older children. Student attempted to commit suicide in 1939. Doctor disputed claim that student attempted to commit suicide.

Principal concluded that second suicide attempt by another student was in an effort to discredit staff member. His investigation concluded that '[n]o punishment was inflicted on the first offender, but the last one was well spanked in the presence of an R.C.M.P. official.
In January 1903, a boy with tuberculosis was isolated from other students. Also cases of pneumonia and scrofulous sores at the school.
On April 8, 1942, two classroom buildings were completely destroyed by fire.
